speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the limp and localized pain you're experiencing, where exactly is the pain located and how long have you been feeling it? Is it constant or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: "My knee hurts, especially when I run or play soccer. It's mostly on the left side, and it feels like it's inside my knee. Sometimes it doesn't hurt as much, but when I've been playing for a while, it starts to feel sore and I have to limp a little bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: That helps narrow it down a bit. Can you tell me more about when the pain started, was it sudden or did it come on gradually over time, and have you recently had any injuries or trauma to your left knee? Have you noticed any swelling or redness around the affected area?

speaker: Patient
text: "I don't remember exactly when it started, but my mom says it's been a few weeks. I didn't fall or hurt myself, it just started hurting one day. Sometimes my knee looks a little puffy after I've been playing, but it doesn't look red or anything."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's helpful to know. Have you noticed any clicking, snapping, or locking sensations in your left knee when you move it, and does the pain feel like it's coming from a specific spot, such as the front, side, or back of your knee? Does the pain ever wake you up at night or is it mostly just during or after activity?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, sometimes when I bend my knee, I feel like it's clicking or something, but it doesn't really hurt when that happens. The pain feels like it's mostly in the front of my knee, and it doesn't usually wake me up at night unless I've been playing a lot during the day and then I might feel it a little bit when I'm lying down."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your activities and how they affect your knee pain, for example, are there any specific movements or actions that make the pain worse, such as jumping, twisting, or climbing stairs? And have you tried resting your knee or applying ice to see if that helps alleviate the pain?

speaker: Patient
text: "Running and playing soccer make my knee hurt the most. Jumping and kicking the ball also makes it feel worse. Sometimes when I'm sitting still for a while, like in class, my knee doesn't hurt as much, but when I get up and start moving around again, it starts to feel sore."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like high-impact activities are exacerbating the pain. Can you tell me if you've noticed any weakness in your left leg or difficulty straightening your knee, and have you tried modifying your activities or taking regular breaks to rest your knee?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, sometimes my leg feels a little weak when I'm running, like it's not as strong as my other leg. And yeah, we've tried taking breaks during recess and sitting down for a bit, and that seems to help a little. My mom also got me an ice pack that I use sometimes after I've been playing, and that helps too."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's great to hear that the ice pack and rest have been helping a bit. Can you tell me if you've noticed any difference in your knee pain when you're walking up or down stairs, and does it feel like your knee is stable or does it feel like it might give way when you're standing or walking?

speaker: Patient
text: "Uh-huh, yeah... when I'm walking up stairs, my knee hurts a bit more than when I'm walking down. And sometimes, like when I'm running or jumping, it feels like my knee might give way or something, but it never actually does. It just feels kinda wobbly, I guess."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's very helpful to know. Can you tell me if you've experienced any numbness or tingling sensations in your left leg or foot, and have you noticed any difficulty walking on different surfaces, such as uneven ground or slippery floors? REQUEST TEST: Knee_X-Ray

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: No significant findings on the X-ray of the knee, suggesting no obvious fractures, dislocations, or other bone abnormalities. However, it's worth noting that the patient's symptoms and physical examination results suggest potential issues with the hip, rather than the knee itself. Further evaluation of the hip may be necessary to determine the cause of the patient's symptoms. Additionally, an X-ray of the left hip was previously taken, which showed flattening and fragmentation of the left femoral head consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease.

speaker: Doctor
text: "I'd like to take a closer look at your hip, can you tell me if you've experienced any pain or discomfort in that area, perhaps when you're walking or running? And have you noticed any limitations in your range of motion, such as difficulty bending or straightening your hip?" REQUEST TEST: Hip_MRI

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Unfortunately, the Hip MRI results are not available in the current data. However, previous X-ray results of the left hip showed flattening and fragmentation of the left femoral head consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Additionally, the Musculoskeletal Examination revealed tenderness on palpation of the left hip, pain elicited with passive motion of the hip, and full range of motion in the knee, but with pain in the hip. NORMAL READINGS are not applicable here as some relevant data is available.

speaker: Doctor
text: Given the previous X-ray results showing flattening and fragmentation of the left femoral head consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, and the musculoskeletal examination findings of tenderness on palpation of the left hip and pain with passive motion, I'd like to ask: Can you tell me more about your activities and how they've changed since you started experiencing pain, have you had to limit or avoid any specific activities due to discomfort in your hip or knee?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I've had to stop playing soccer for a while because it hurts my knee too much. I also don't like to run as much anymore because it makes my knee feel sore. Sometimes I'll just walk instead of run during recess, and that feels a little better. My mom says I can still play games that don't make my knee hurt, like video games or board games, so that's what I've been doing more of."

speaker: Doctor
text: "It sounds like you've had to make some significant changes to your activities to manage your pain. Can you tell me if you've noticed any difference in your pain level when you're sitting or lying down, and does it feel like your hip or knee is uncomfortable even when you're not moving around?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, when I'm sitting still for a long time, my knee doesn't hurt as much. But if I've been sitting for a while and then I stand up, it feels a little stiff and sore. And at night, when I'm lying down, my knee usually doesn't hurt unless I've been playing a lot during the day. Sometimes my mom will rub my knee or hip and that feels nice, it helps me relax."

speaker: Doctor
text: "That's helpful to know. Can you tell me if you've noticed any difference in your pain level when you're bearing weight on your left leg, such as when you're standing on one leg or jumping, and does it feel like your hip or knee is unstable when you're doing these activities?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, when I'm standing on one leg, like on my left leg, it feels a little wobbly and my knee hurts more. And when I'm jumping, it feels like my knee is going to give way or something, so I try not to jump as much anymore. Sometimes I'll hold onto something, like the wall or a chair, to help me balance when I'm standing on one leg."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, that's very helpful to know. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort in your groin area or upper thigh, and does it feel like the pain is radiating from your hip down to your knee?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, sometimes I feel a little pain in my groin area, especially when I'm running or kicking a ball. It's not as bad as the pain in my knee, but it's there. And yeah, it feels like the pain is coming from higher up, like my hip or something, and then it goes down to my knee. My mom says it might be related to why my knee hurts, but I don't really understand how."

speaker: Doctor
text: "That's very helpful information, thank you for sharing that with me. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or stiffness in your hip when you're first getting up in the morning, after you've been sleeping for a while, and does it take some time for your hip to 'loosen up' as you start moving around?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, my mom says I'm a little stiff in the mornings, and it takes me a bit to get moving. My hip feels kinda tight, like it needs to warm up or something. And yeah, after I've been walking around for a bit, it feels looser and not as sore. Sometimes my mom will help me stretch my leg out a bit before I get out of bed, and that seems to help too."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like you experience some morning stiffness in your hip, which improves as you start moving around. That's consistent with some hip conditions. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort when you're climbing up stairs, and does it feel like your hip is bothering you more when you're going up versus coming down?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I don't really like climbing stairs that much anymore because it makes my knee hurt. But I think it's my hip that's really hurting, too. It feels like it's harder to go up the stairs than to come down, and sometimes I'll hold onto the railing to help me pull myself up. My mom says it's okay to take my time and not rush when I'm going up the stairs, so I try to do that."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like climbing stairs is challenging for you due to both knee and hip pain. Can you tell me if you've noticed any difference in your ability to walk or run on flat surfaces versus uneven surfaces, such as trails or grassy fields?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I don't like running on uneven surfaces because it makes my knee feel wobbly and it hurts more. On flat surfaces, like the playground or soccer field, it's a little better, but still not great. Sometimes I'll trip or stumble when I'm running on grass or trails, and that makes me worried that I'll hurt my knee even more."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like uneven surfaces can exacerbate your symptoms and make you feel less stable. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort when you're sitting with your legs crossed or bent at an angle, and does it feel like your hip is uncomfortable in certain positions?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, when I sit with my legs crossed, it feels a little tight in my hip and knee. And if I bend my leg up too high, like when I'm sitting on the floor, it hurts a bit. My mom says I should try to keep my legs straight or stretched out when I'm sitting, so I've been trying to do that more often."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like certain positions can exacerbate your hip and knee pain. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort when you're getting in or out of a car, or when you're standing up from a seated position, and does it feel like your hip is stiff or sore after being in one position for too long?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, getting in and out of the car can be kinda hard because I have to bend my leg and twist my body, and that makes my knee hurt. And when I'm standing up from sitting down, like from a chair or the couch, it feels like my hip is stiff and it takes me a second to get moving. My mom says it's okay to take my time and not rush when I'm getting up, so I try to do that. Sometimes I'll use my hands to help push myself up from the seat, and that seems to help a bit."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like you experience some stiffness and pain in your hip when changing positions or getting in and out of tight spaces. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort when you're carrying heavy objects, such as a backpack or books, and does it feel like the weight is putting additional stress on your hip or knee?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, my backpack can be kinda heavy sometimes, and when I'm carrying it, I can feel the weight pulling on my hip and knee. It doesn't hurt too much, but it feels like it's making my knee a little more sore than usual. My mom says I should try to pack lighter or use a backpack with better straps, so I've been trying to do that."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, so it sounds like carrying heavy objects can exacerbate your symptoms and put additional stress on your hip and knee. Can you tell me if you've noticed any pain or discomfort when you're doing activities that involve pivoting or quick changes of direction, such as dancing or playing tag?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I don't like playing tag as much anymore because it makes my knee hurt when I have to quickly turn or change direction. And when I'm dancing, like in gym class, I try to avoid spinning or twisting too much because that makes my hip and knee feel sore. Sometimes I'll just walk or jog instead of running when we're playing games that involve a lot of quick turns."

speaker: Doctor
text:
DIAGNOSIS READY: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD)

The majority of the doctors agree that the patient's symptoms and test results are consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, characterized by hip pain, stiffness, limited mobility, and X-ray findings of flattening and fragmentation of the left femoral head. Although some doctors consider other possibilities, such as slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) or hip dysplasia, the consensus is that LCPD is the most likely diagnosis.

Note: Cholecystitis is not a relevant diagnosis in this case, as it refers to inflammation of the gallbladder and is not related to the patient's symptoms or test results.
